items.question: I don't need a website — I have enough work from referrals
items.answer: That's great! But a website lets you choose better jobs and charge higher prices. When clients see your professional online presence, they're willing to pay premium rates. Plus, referrals dry up eventually — a website gives you a consistent stream of new leads.

items.question: It's too expensive
items.answer: A website pays for itself after 1-2 new clients. If you charge $500+ per job, the $1,000 investment is covered almost immediately. Plus, the monthly plan is less than what you'd pay for a single hour of work — and it includes hosting, maintenance, and compliance monitoring.

items.question: I don't have time for this
items.answer: We designed the process specifically for busy craftsmen. The brief takes 15 minutes. One 15-minute call. That's it. We handle absolutely everything else — design, development, hosting, domain setup, and ongoing maintenance. You don't need to learn anything technical.

items.question: I have a Facebook page — isn't that enough?
items.answer: Facebook is a complement, not a replacement for a website. Google doesn't index Facebook profiles well. AI assistants like ChatGPT can't recommend you based on your Facebook page. And many clients expect a 'real' business to have its own website — a Facebook-only presence can look unprofessional.

items.question: Can I update the website myself?
items.answer: You don't need to. Content changes are included in the Premium plan (unlimited) or available on request for the Basic plan. Just email us what you want changed, and we'll do it within 24 hours. No technical skills required on your end.

items.question: What if I want to cancel?
items.answer: You can cancel the monthly plan anytime — no questions asked. If you cancel, you keep ownership of your domain. We'll help you migrate to another provider if needed. We're confident you'll stay because the value is obvious, but there's zero lock-in.

hero.subtitle: 97% of audited Norwegian websites fail accessibility requirements. Digdir conducts random checks and publishes results. Is your website compliant?
hero.source: According to Tilsynet for universell utforming av IKT, 67 out of 69 audited websites (97%) had accessibility violations. The agency conducts approximately 250 audits per year.

problem.title: What is WCAG and why does it matter?
problem.subtitle: Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) ensure websites are usable by people with disabilities. In Norway, it's not optional — it's the law.

items.title: Norwegian law requires WCAG 2.0 AA
items.description: The Forskrift om universell utforming av IKT-løsninger mandates that all websites must be accessible. This applies to both public and private sector businesses.

items.title: Digdir conducts audits and publishes results
items.description: Tilsynet for universell utforming av IKT performs random website audits. Failed audits are published publicly, and you'll receive an order to fix the issues within a deadline.

items.title: 97% of websites fail compliance checks
items.description: The vast majority of Norwegian websites have accessibility issues. Your website likely has problems you're not aware of — most issues are invisible to untrained eyes.

items.title: Your current site probably has issues
items.description: Common problems include poor color contrast, missing alt texts, keyboard navigation issues, and improper form labels. These affect real users and violate the law.
